prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SerpMain Tile1 HCN, etc
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: mosaic maps of HCN, HCO+, SiO lower half of field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral line: In the first spectrometer setup, we can observe 5 different lines (H13CO+, H13CN, SiO, HCN, and HCO+) at once, in 3 basebands. The second spectrometer setup includes 3 lines (CS, C18O, and 13CO) in 2 basebands. The spectral lines to be observed will have widths in the range 5 to 20 km/s (FWZI), so a spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s will give good sampling across the lines. Therefore we select the 1/2-band portion of the spectrometer channels for the HCN and HCO+ main isotopes, expected to be the strongest lines. To keep the data rate within the 12 MB/sec limit, we select the 1/4-band options for H13CN, H13CO+, and SiO, giving a resolution of 0.4 km/s. Since these lines are expected to be weaker, spectral averaging is appropriate.
Continuum: The remaining basebands in each spectrometer setup will be used for continuum, spanning the accessible frequency coverage of the Band 3 receivers for optimum sensitivity (roughly 85 to 112 GHz). Four continuum BBs of 1.875 GHz each will yield continuum sensitivity adequate to meet the science objectives for detection of compact continuum sources throughout the mosaiced field at 12 sec integration time per pointing (see Sensitivity Justification).

Our published single-dish maps of 13CO emission from the target region (Burleigh et al. 2013) show structures on the order of 2 arcmin in size. CARMA and HERSCHEL images of other gas or dust tracers show structures barely resolved at 7 arcsec resolution (FWHM). There is detectable CO emission well beyond the 7.5 arcmin X 8 arcmin field, but the region for mosaic imaging encompasses the densest core of the molecular cloud, which is also the site of the greatest concentration of young stellar objects and protostellar cores. This proposal aims to have uniform sensitivity across all angular scales from 120 arcsec down to the ALMA resolution of 4 arcsec over the entire mapped region. Therefore we require use of the ACA and the TP observing modes in addition to the 12-m array.

Spectral line: We specify a brightness temperature RMS of 0.2 K in one 0.2 km/s spectral channel to detect lines with adequate S/N to determine kinematic properties (velocity centroid, width, velocity gradients). The line widths are expected to be 5 to 20 km/s (FWZI) so a spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s is adequate and allows for spectrum averaging to increase S/N if needed for weak emission. The requirement for this spectral sensitivity sets the integration time per mosaic pointing at 12.1 sec on source.
Continuum: Continuum sources are expected to be compact with up to 20 mJy/beam (as found by CARMA images in Lee et al. 2014). These relatively weak sources will not compromise the spectral dynamic range. Continuum sources are expected to fill a small fraction of the mapping field (i.e., as protostellar cores). At 12 sec integration time per pointing center, one continuum baseband of 1.875 GHz gives a continuum rms of 0.43 mJy/beam. With 4 continuum BBs, averaging gives 0.22 mJy, so our detection limit for compact continuum sources is about 1 mJy/beam (5-sigma), a factor of 6 lower than that achieved by previous interferometer mapping with CARMA (Lee et al. 2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SerpMain Tile1 CS&CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: mosaic maps of CS and CO lower half of field

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: mosaic maps of CS and CO upper half of field

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will map the central 7.5' x 8' of the Serpens Main molecular cloud core in 8 different molecular lines and the continnum, all in Band 3, with uniform sensitivity across the range of spatial scales from the resolution limit of 4 arcsec (0.008 pc) up to the size of the mapping field (1 pc). This region covers the densest part of the cloud and is the site of currently most active star formation as shown by Spitzer detection of YSOs in the earliest evolutionary stages. Molecular lines to be observed in Band 3 are HCO+, H13CO+, HCN, H13CN, SiO, CS, C18O, and 13CO. These lines trace gas dynamics such as turbulence, core formation, and bipolar outflows, that affect the star formation process. The continuum observations will be analyzed to derive a core mass function complete to <0.08 M_solar. Molecular abundances will be examined to look for depletion in dense cores as indicators of evolutionary state, and for effects of grain heating or destruction near YSOs with outflows.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Vienna, University of
